pr_title: Add intermediate storage for customized state

timeline.message: add intermidiate storage for customized state
add intermidiate storage for customized state

timeline.bodyText:
This map is long and potentially introduces duplicate code since we have a similar code for the current state.
Can we abstract a type for the stateMap that covers (resourceName -> (Partition -> (instanceName -> customizedState))) section? Then this map class can be used in both CustomizedStateOutput and CurrentStateOutput.
timeline.author: jiajunwang
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,135 @@

+import java.util.Collections;
+import java.util.HashMap;
+import java.util.Map;
+import java.util.Set;
+import org.apache.helix.model.CustomizedState;
+import org.apache.helix.model.Partition;
+
+public class CustomizedStateOutput {
+  // stateType -> (resourceName -> (Partition -> (instanceName -> customizedState)))
+  private final Map<String, Map<String, Map<Partition, Map<String, String>>>> _customizedStateMap;

replies.bodyText: CurrentStateOutput has more maps that CustomizedStateOutput. And those maps are with different types of keys. I feel it's actually easier to know what the map has and what exactly each level of keys are by looking at the map. If we have another class of hierarchical map, we will still need to pass the types for the key, and how many levels there are, and if we only manipulate map in that class, it is harder to users to understand the map logic.
replies.author: zhangmeng916

timeline.bodyText: nit, customizedStateName -> customizedStateType or type?
timeline.author: jiajunwang

replies.bodyText: And lamda shall fit here very well.
replies.author: jiajunwang

replies.bodyText: It's moved to participantStateCache logic and updated.
replies.author: zhangmeng916

timeline.bodyText: nit, Just call it keys or stateKeys? For shortening the code a little bit.
timeline.author: jiajunwang

timeline.bodyText: As we discussed offline, we should either leverage propertyCache class or try to combine the common part of this cache and the current state cache.
timeline.author: jiajunwang

timeline.bodyText:
Thanks for the change. Looks great.
One suggestion is that this change will reduce the genericity of AbstractDataCache. Can we add a middle class called "AbstractParticipantStateCache" as a child class of the AbstractDataCache?
timeline.author: jiajunwang

timeline.bodyText: You can keep the original name refresh() so it fits the style.
timeline.author: jiajunwang

     return refreshedPropertyMap;
   }

+import org.slf4j.LoggerFactory;
+
+public class CustomizedStateCache extends AbstractDataCache<CustomizedState> {
+  private static final Logger LOG = LoggerFactory.getLogger(CurrentStateCache.class.getName());

replies.bodyText: Let's keep it separated, so that in the computation logic, there's no confusion.
replies.author: zhangmeng916

timeline.bodyText: duplicate and return is safer.
timeline.author: jiajunwang

timeline.bodyText: Same here. Please copy the map and then return.
timeline.author: jiajunwang

timeline.bodyText: This method should call getResourceCustomizedStateMap() to avoid duplicate code.
timeline.author: jiajunwang

timeline.bodyText:
This method should call the other getCustomizedStateMap() to avoid duplicate code.
BTW, can we have a better name to differentiate?
timeline.author: jiajunwang

timeline.bodyText: Always copy and then return.
timeline.author: jiajunwang

timeline.bodyText: Add a simple comment for this class, please.
timeline.author: jiajunwang

timeline.bodyText: getName() is not preferred. Please just pass the class as the parameter.
timeline.author: jiajunwang

timeline.bodyText: Do we really need these 2 constructors?
timeline.author: jiajunwang

timeline.bodyText: As an abstract class, usually, we only need one constructor for the children.
timeline.author: jiajunwang

timeline.bodyText:
Although it is an abstract class, level one for the instancename should be fixed. We can keep it here for clearer code.
As for level 2 and 3, we might want to comment it with an example for the other code readers.
timeline.author: jiajunwang

timeline.bodyText: log error (or warning) if any mismatch keys.
timeline.author: jiajunwang

timeline.bodyText: nit, can we simplify this block a little bit. For example, putIfAbsent, etc.
timeline.author: jiajunwang

replies.bodyText: I tried a bit, but it cannot really be simplified by using putIfAbsent, as the next level map still need to use the previous map.
replies.author: zhangmeng916

timeline.bodyText: Since you are creating a new map every time already, is it still necessary to make it unmodifiable?
timeline.author: jiajunwang

timeline.bodyText: So for the first condition, the liveInstance is kind of the restrictedKeys, right? Can we put this logic to a protected method and leave it to the child class? This will help to cleanup the abstract class.
timeline.author: jiajunwang

replies.bodyText: Basically you have an abstract method getParticipantStateKeys and called here. The children will implement this method separately with the different logic.
replies.author: jiajunwang

timeline.bodyText: Optional, both getParticipantStates() methods could be protected and let the children class wrap them and implement with more meaningful public methods.
timeline.author: jiajunwang

replies.bodyText: I changed the key names here. I feel it's ok to leave it here as it only returns some mapping.
replies.author: zhangmeng916

timeline.bodyText:
The original logic is actually confusing here. Passing an empty new map here is much easier for people to understand.
Since it won't change the logic, I suggest you just change it to make it clean : )
timeline.author: jiajunwang

replies.bodyText: I changed the map in ParticipantCache.
replies.author: zhangmeng916

timeline.bodyText: If the input participantStateKeys is always empty and is a return value, why not just let this method return a set for the keys?
timeline.author: jiajunwang

timeline.bodyText: This should be an abstract method with no implementation. So the child class is required to implement it.
timeline.author: jiajunwang

replies.bodyText: Usually, this class should be protected only. Since it is only called in side this class.
replies.author: jiajunwang

timeline.bodyText: This one as well. Try to use more abstract methods if the implementation is not possible in this abstract class.
timeline.author: jiajunwang

timeline.bodyText: As we talked offline, let's try to hide restrictedKeys as an internal field and don't require the caller to pass on every refresh call.
timeline.author: jiajunwang

timeline.message: fix comments in participant state cache

timeline.bodyText: Should this boolean be fixed once the class is coded? Overall, I don't think we need it. Just call refreshSnapshot() anyway. If there is no such implementation, the child class won't implement it anyway.
timeline.author: jiajunwang

timeline.bodyText:
Since the customized state cache won't support snapshot for now, just comment on this method as OPTIONAL to be implemented. If the child class does not support snapshot, just do nothing. And we don't need the boolean to differentiate.
We might want to support it later though.
timeline.author: jiajunwang

timeline.bodyText: Intuitively, this one should be called getCustomizedStateMap()
timeline.author: jiajunwang

timeline.bodyText: Intuitively, this one should be called getResourceCustomizedStateMap()
timeline.author: jiajunwang

timeline.bodyText: Intuitively, this one should be called getPartitionCustomizedStateMap()
timeline.author: jiajunwang

timeline.bodyText: This one can be called getReplicaCustomizedState()
timeline.author: jiajunwang

timeline.bodyText: How this is used? I would suggest adding this only when we have the usage in the PR.
timeline.author: jiajunwang
